newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Rallying MOL steals show on Budapest mkt.
newsitem.headline: Rallying MOL steals show on Budapest mkt.

text.p: Surging stocks in oil and gas firm MOL overshadowed the Hungarian market on Friday but its gains just about offset losses elsewhere on the market, traders said.
The BUX index of the Budapest Stock Exchange, which celebrates its seventh birthday on Saturday, finished at a preliminary 6,460.13 points, up 9.45.

Trading in MOL started with a rally to a new record level of 4,185 forints on expectations of the size of the gas price increase but some intraday profit-taking trimmed earlier gains. MOL finished at 4,090 forints, up 160.
"Expectations of the gas price increase boosted MOL's price further but the stock could not hold 4,100 forints as many began to lock in profits," said Peter Nagy of Postabank Securities.

Chemicals and pharmaceuticals stocks were also hit by profit-taking but Nagy said these papers had strong support levels. "One can see the support levels of certain stocks at current lower levels," Nagy said.
He said chemicals TVK had a support at between 3,000 to 3,050 forints, MOL at 4,000 forints, pharmaceuticals Richter at 15,600 and Egis at 11,500 and OTP Bank at 4,500.
The size of the quarterly energy price increase is a sensitive component of MOL's earnings and, since it is the market's largest capitalised paper, was likely to lead the rest of the bourse.
Hungary's Industry and Trade Ministry said earlier on Friday it would decide on the price increase on Monday.
The apparent upper end of the market's expectations is 17 percent while the lower end seems to be at 10 percent.

"There is potential that it could only be at 10 percent level," said Tommy Erdei, analyst at ABN AMRO Hoare Govett in Budapest. "If it does come out at 10 percent, I would think that MOL would certainly not go upwards," he said. "If it comes out at 17 percent then MOL is going to continue to go up."

Erdei added that apart from the energy price increase there might be some volatility in the downward direction, which is a usual phenomenon before the earnings season as people get a little worried about companies' performance.
Hungarian companies have to submit their first half earnings reports to the bourse by August 15.
On Friday, tile maker Zalakeramia had a strong demand at between 7,200 and 7,280 forints, Nagy said. The paper closed at 7,280, down 170.
TVK closed at 3,100, down 65; Richter at 15,650 forints, down 55; Egis at 11,580, down 120 and OTP at 4,525, down 20.
